QuestionTxt: I would like to read you a list of names of different people active in politics.  For each one, please tell me, first whether you've heard of the person, then, if so, please tell me whether you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person.  If I name someone you don't know too much about, just tell me and we'll go on to the next one....John McCain...(If Favorable/Unfavorable, ask:) Would that be strongly favorable/unfavorable or just somewhat favorable/unfavorable?
SurveyOrg: Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research; Public Opinion Strategies
SampleDesc: Likely voters in presidential battleground states
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted September 18 and 20, 2008.  Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2004 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2008 election.  The battleground states were Alaska, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Indiana, Iowa, Michigan, Missouri, Montana, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Wisconsin.

If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...John McCain...Give...John McCain a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. QuestionTxt: (Now, I'd like to rate your feelings toward some people and organizations, with one hundred meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold.  You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization.  If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...John McCain...Give...John McCain a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (If Don't know, ask:) Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of...John McCain, or have you never heard of...John McCain?
StudyNote: Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2004 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are proobably or almost certain to vote in the 2008 election.

QuestionTxt: (Now, I'd like to rate your feelings toward some people and organizations, with one hundred meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold.  You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization.  If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...John McCain...Give...John McCain a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (If Don't know, ask:) Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of...John McCain, or have you never heard of...John McCain?
StudyNote: Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2004 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2008 election.

If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...John McCain...Give...John McCain a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (I am now going to read you a series of statements about Hillary Clinton. Please indicate whether each make you more or less favorable toward her?...Much more favorable, somewhat more favorable, less favorable)...Hillary Clinton supported the Kennedy-McCain Immigration Bill that would have created a temporary worker visa and would have distributed visa fees to hospitals to help pay for healthcare for immigrants. The Bush Administration has failed to meet the basic requirements for meaningful immigration reform. Hillary Clinton wants to continue the American tradition of welcoming immigrants who are trying to build a better life for their families, while strengthening national security in a post 9-11 (September 11, 2001, the date of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon) world.
SourceDoc: PSB October 2007 California likely Democratic primary voters
StudyNote: This survey was conducted on behalf of Hillary Clinton. These data have been made available with the support of the Society of Presidential Pollsters and the Special Collections Research Center, George Washington Libraries and Academic Innovation, The George Washington University. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for access to materials in the Mark Penn Digital Polling Data Collection and Oral History. Speccoll@gwu.edu

If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...John McCain...Give...John McCain a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. QuestionTxt: Do the following statements make you more or less favorable towards Hillary Clinton?...Takes on Bush & GOP: Hillary Clinton knows when to work with Republicans and when you have to draw the line. She had the guts to take on George (W) Bush when he tried to privatize Social Security, when he wouldn't give first responders from 9/11 the health treatment they needed and she is taking Bush on over the War in Iraq. But she has also been praised for working with Republicans. Newt Gingrich calls her "very smart, very professional? Republican Senator Lindsey Graham says if "I'm looking for ally on the other side, she's one of the first people I call", and John McCain says "l am sure that Senator Clinton would make a good president." Hillary Clinton is tough enough to stand up to the Republicans and win and get America back on track, but she can work with Republicans to get things done.
StudyNote: This survey was conducted on behalf of Hillary Clinton. These data have been made available with the support of the Society of Presidential Pollsters and the Special Collections Research Center, George Washington Libraries and Academic Innovation, The George Washington University. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for access to materials in the Mark Penn Digital Polling Data Collection and Oral History. Speccoll@gwu.edu

National likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2004 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2008 election.

QuestionTxt: (I'd like to rate your feelings toward some people and organizations, with one hundred meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold. You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization. If you have no opinion or have never heard of that person or organization, please say so.) John McCain....(If don't know, ask:) Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of John McCain, or have you never heard of John McCain?
StudyNote: National registered likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 1996 presidential election for president, were ineligible, or too young and they said they will probably vote or are almost certain to vote in the presidential election in 2000.

(Now I would like to read some statements a Democratic candidate could make about this proposal (President (George W.) Bush has proposed setting up a special trial system at Guantanamo Bay for suspected terrorists.  While they would get a military judge and jury they would not have the right to hear classified evidence against them).  Please tell me if you would be more or less favorable toward a Democrat who made each statement.)...I stand with military leaders and other combat veterans like John McCain, who oppose the President's plans because they believe it is illegal and harmful to American interests. StudyNote: Likely voters are registered voters who said they are absolutely certain/very likely to vote in the 2006 election.

You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization.  If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...John McCain...Give...John McCain a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. SubPopulation: Asked of Form A half sample
